Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I stood in the hallway, clutching the ceremonial cloth my mother had handed me, her eyes shining with pride. “You’re the eldest now,” she whispered, “it’s your turn to lead the ceremony. Our family’s tradition depends on you.” My heart pounded with the weight of her words, the expectation to honor generations before me pressing down. But my phone buzzed—a reminder that I had to vote before the polls closed. I rushed to the polling station, my mind still tangled in prayers and rituals.

Inside, the poll worker frowned at my ballot envelope. “The signature smudged. Please re-sign here, exactly as before, or your vote might not count.” I hesitated, remembering my mother’s warning: “Never sign anything important on the day of the ceremony—it’s bad luck.” The traditions I was raised with clashed with the civic duty I believed in. My hands trembled, torn between honoring my family’s beliefs and following the rules that protected my vote. The pressure from both sides squeezed my chest, and I stood frozen, pen hovering, unable to move forward without betraying one part of myself.
